comment: An open reading frame with 58% identity to SERC_METBF is present but no protein was predicted
An open reading frame with 41% identity to AROK_ECOLI is present but no protein was predicted
An frameshift error in the genome sequence prevented this protein from being predicted (PMID:29324779)

This genome does not encode a standard homoserine kinase, but does encode a standard threonine synthase (BT2401). BT2402 is related to phosphoglycerate mutases and is proposed to move phosphate groups to homoserine based on conserved gene order (see TIGR02535). Indeed, BT2402 is required for growth in minimal media unless threonine is provided. However, BT2402 did not complement a thrB- strain of E. coli (Hualan Liu, personal communication). Insertions in BT2402 could be polar on the threonine synthase (which is downstream), but insertions in either orientation seem deficient in growth in minimal media. Overall, the role of BT2402 remains uncertain.

This organism probably uses succinylated intermediates, as Echvi_3551 is a good candidate for the succinyltransferase DapD. But the aminotransferase and the desuccinylase cannot be found. Alternatively, Echvi_0124 could be a diverged diamopimelate aminotransferase.
Echvi_1811 could be a diverged phosphoserine aminotransferase. It appears to be essential (PMID:29769716)
Echvi_0122 may be a diverged 3-phosphoshikimate 1-carboxyvinyl transferase (also known as 5-enolpyruvylshikimate-3-phosphate synthase). It appears to be essential (PMID:29769716)
Echvi_0221 may be a diverged serine acetyltransferase. It appears to be essential (PMID:29769716).
This genome does not encode a standard homoserine kinase, but does encode a standard threonine synthase (Dshi_1146).
This genome has several weak candidates for phosphoserine phosphatase.
This genome and others of its species (Dyella japonica) have a short IlvI (regulatory subunit of acetolactate synthase), i.e. N515DRAFT_0566. The conservation suggests that it is functional.
This genome and others of its species (Dyella japonica) have a short IlvI (regulatory subunit of acetolactate synthase), i.e. N515DRAFT_0566. The conservation suggests that it is functional.

This organism probably uses the transsulfuration pathway (MetB = N515DRAFT_4363 is important for growth in minimal media). N515DRAFT_4305 is likely to be cystathionine beta-lyase (MetC), but it is also very similar to a characterized cystathionine gamma-lyase (Q5H4T8), so we cannot be confident.
This genome and others of its species (Dyella japonica) have a short IlvI (regulatory subunit of acetolactate synthase), i.e. N515DRAFT_0566. The conservation suggests that it is functional.
This genome does not seem to encode the standard SerACB pathway of serine synthesis
This genome does not seem to encode the standard SerACB pathway of serine synthesis
DvMF_0940 may be a diverged histidinol phosphatase. It appears to be essential (PMID:29769716).
This genome does not seem to encode the standard SerACB pathway of serine synthesis

The chorismate synthase appears to be truncated or split into two reading frames (SO3078.2 and SO_3079). Inspection of sequencing data (from TnSeq) shows that this frameshift is an error in the original genome sequence.
This genome does not encode a standard diaminopimelate desuccinylase (DapE).
This organism does not contain a standard homoserine kinase, but does encode a standard threonine synthase (PGA1_c06310).
An open reading frame with 67% identity to KPRS_ECOLI is present but no protein was predicted
By comparing the published assembly to alternate assemblies, we identified a region that was missing. It included an open reading frame with 84% identity to METZ_PSEAE.

Synpcc7942_1763 could be a diverged histidinol-phosphate phosphatase, but it is not required for growth. (This is a strictly autotrophic organism.) This implies that there is another novel histidinol phosphatase (and the function of Synpcc7942_1763 remains uncertain).
Synpcc7942_0881 may be a diverged prephenate dehydratase. It appears to be essential (PMID:26508635)

Synpcc7942_2078 could be a diverged phosphoserine phosphatase, but it is not required for growth. (This is a strictly autotrophic organism.) This implies that there is another novel phosphoserine phosphatase (and the function of Synpcc7942_2078 remains uncertain)
Synpcc7942_1030 may be a diverged histidinol-phosphate aminotransferase. It appears to be essential (PMID:26508635)
DVU2940 may be a diverged histidinol phosphatase. It appears to be essential (PMID:29769716).
This genome does not seem to encode the standard SerACB pathway of serine synthesis
